comment: [minor] (auto-passed) The translation 'adopter' is incorrect; it should be 'adopter' in the context of the verb 'adopt' as it refers to the act of adopting, not a person who adopts.; The native translations provided for both definitions are accurate but could be more concise.
definition_data: {"word": "adopt", "phonetic": "/əˈdɑpt/", "suggestion": null, "definitions": [{"examples": ["She decided to adopt a more relaxed attitude towards her work.", "He adopted the persona of a confident public speaker during his presentations.", "The organization will adopt new sustainable practices to enhance its environmental impact.", "The committee adopted a new policy to improve workplace safety.", "They adopted a more collaborative approach to problem-solving."], "definition": "to take on a role, responsibility, or attitude in a formal or intentional manner, such as accepting a new position or viewpoint.", "cultural_notes": null, "part_of_speech": "verb", "definition_native": "prendre un rôle, une responsabilité ou une attitude de manière formelle ou intentionnelle, comme accepter une nouvelle position ou un nouveau point de vue."}, {"examples": ["The couple decided to adopt the surname 'Smith' for their children after their marriage.", "The company adopted a new approach to marketing that focuses on digital platforms.", "She adopted a healthier lifestyle after her doctor's advice, including regular exercise and better nutrition.", "The family adopted a new strategy for managing their finances effectively.", "The school adopted a new curriculum to better meet the needs of its students."], "definition": "to choose or select something, such as a name, method, or practice, often implying a formal decision or commitment to that choice.", "cultural_notes": null, "part_of_speech": "verb", "definition_native": "choisir ou sélectionner quelque chose, comme un nom, une méthode ou une pratique, impliquant souvent une décision formelle ou un engagement envers ce choix."}], "translations": ["adopter"], "valid_word_score": 1.0}

definition_data: {"word": "accept", "phonetic": "/ækˈsɛpt/", "suggestion": null, "definitions": [{"examples": ["She accepted the job offer and started working on Monday.", "He accepted the award with a grateful speech.", "The company accepted the terms of the contract.", "The students accepted the challenge and worked hard to complete the project.", "The government accepted the resignation of the minister.", "He accepted the invitation to the party."], "definition": "to receive something willingly, to agree to something proposed, to acknowledge receipt of something, or to take on a responsibility or obligation.", "cultural_notes": "In some cultures, accepting something may imply a sense of obligation or duty, rather than a genuine willingness.", "part_of_speech": "verb", "definition_native": "recevoir quelque chose de manière volontaire, accepter quelque chose qui est proposé, accuser réception de quelque chose, ou assumer une responsabilité ou une obligation."}], "translations": ["accepter"], "valid_word_score": 1.0}

definition_data: {"word": "awkward", "phonetic": "/ˈɔːkwərd/", "suggestion": null, "definitions": [{"examples": ["The awkward silence between them was palpable.", "She felt awkward in her new shoes.", "The conversation became awkward after he mentioned politics.", "He had an awkward time trying to dance with her.", "The teenager was going through an awkward phase.", "His awkward movements made everyone laugh."], "definition": "Causing discomfort or embarrassment; clumsy or lacking grace; lacking coordination or skill.", "cultural_notes": "In some cultures, awkwardness is seen as a normal part of development, especially during adolescence.", "part_of_speech": "adjective", "definition_native": "Provoquant de l'inconfort ou de la gêne; maladroit ou manquant de grâce; manquant de coordination ou d'habileté."}], "translations": ["gauche", "maladroit", "difficile", "maladroit"], "valid_word_score": 1.0}
